parse

public static org.w3c.dom.Document parse(byte[] abData,
                                         java.io.File fRelative)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Parses XML from a byte array and returns the document.

Parameters:
abData - Byte array containing an XML file
fRelative - During parsing, relative references (e.g. to DTDs) are resolved as if the input stream was from this specified file (which need not actually exist). Set null to use current directory.
Returns:
DOM document
Throws:
java.io.IOException

parse

public static org.w3c.dom.Document parse(java.io.InputStream is)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Parses XML from an input stream and returns the document. The XML must not contain any references to other files e.g. DTDs.

Parameters:
is - Input stream (note that as far as I know this is not buffered internally so for performance you might wish to buffer it beforehand if it comes from a file or something slow)
Returns:
DOM document
Throws:
java.io.IOException

parse

                                         java.io.File fRelative)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Parses XML from an input stream and returns the document.

Parameters:
is - Input stream (note that as far as I know this is not buffered internally so for performance you might wish to buffer it beforehand if it comes from a file or something slow)
fRelative - During parsing, relative references (e.g. to DTDs) are resolved as if the input stream was from this specified file (which need not actually exist). Set null to use current directory.
Returns:
DOM document
Throws:
java.io.IOException

parse

public static org.w3c.dom.Document parse(java.io.Reader r,
                                         java.io.File fRelative)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Parses XML from an input reader and returns the document.

This is not ideal unless you are certain of character encoding, as the reader has predetermined the character encoding to be used, regardless of any information in the XML declaration.

Parameters:
r - Input reader (note that as far as I know this is not buffered internally so for performance you might wish to buffer it beforehand if it comes from a file or something slow)
fRelative - During parsing, relative references (e.g. to DTDs) are resolved as if the input stream was from this specified file (which need not actually exist). Set null to use current directory.
Returns:
DOM document
Throws:
java.io.IOException

save

public static void save(org.w3c.dom.Element e,
                        java.io.File f)
                 throws java.io.IOException
Saves an XML element to file, omitting XML declaration.

This element and all subelements are saved, but anything else (elements above this in the tree, or sibling elements) is not.

Parameters:
e - Element to save
f - File to save it to
Throws:
java.io.IOException - In the event of I/O or transformation error

                                           java.lang.String sName)
                                    throws XMLException
Returns child element with given name.

If there is more than one child with that name, the first is returned.

Parameters:
nParent - Parent node
sName - Tag name
Returns:
Child element with that name
Throws:
XMLException - If there is no element with that name

XMLException - If child element does not exist

escape

public static java.lang.String escape(java.lang.String sSource)
Escapes a string using XML entities where necessary (use this when writing XML 'by hand' rather than using save methods).

Parameters:
sSource - String that may contain triangle brackets and quotes
Returns:
String that will contain XML entities instead, and has illegal control characters stripped

replaceTokens

public static java.lang.String replaceTokens(java.lang.String sValue,
                                             java.lang.String sBorder,
                                             java.util.Map mReplace)
Replaces tokens safely in a string.

Parameters:
sValue - String to check
sBorder - Border string e.g. %%; must be made of characters that don't need escaping in regexps
mReplace - Replacement map
Returns:
The new or unchanged string

replaceToken

public static java.lang.String replaceToken(java.lang.String sInput,
                                            java.lang.String sBorder,
                                            java.lang.String sToken,
                                            java.lang.String sValue)
Replaces tokens safely in a string.

Parameters:
sInput - String to check
sBorder - Border string e.g. %%; must be made of characters that don't need escaping in regexps
sToken - Token to replace (do not include %% at either end)
sValue - Value for token
Returns:
The new or unchanged string

replaceTokens

public static void replaceTokens(org.w3c.dom.Node n,
                                 java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> mReplace)
Replace tokens in the form %%token-ID%%, anywhere they occur in text or attribute values. %%%% becomes a literal %%. Anything not matched as a token is left alone.

Parameters:
n - Node to begin with
mReplace - Map of token-ID to replacement text

replaceTokens

public static void replaceTokens(org.w3c.dom.Node n,
                                 java.lang.String sBorder,
                                 java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> mReplace)
Replace tokens in the form %%token-ID%%, anywhere they occur in text or attribute values. %%%% becomes a literal %%. Anything not matched as a token is left alone. (You can set the border string to anything, not just %%.)

Parameters:
n - Node to begin with
sBorder - Border string e.g. %%; must be made of characters that don't need escaping in regexps
mReplace - Map of token-ID to replacement text (String) or XML content (Node)

find

public static org.w3c.dom.Element find(org.w3c.dom.Document d,
                                       java.lang.String sAttribute,
                                       java.lang.String sValue)
                                throws XMLException
Finds an element with the given attribute/value pair.

Parameters:
d - document
sAttribute - Desired attribute name
sValue - Desired attribute value
Returns:
First element matching that specification
Throws:
XMLException - If there is no element with that attribute (note: if you don't want this behaviour, try the other find method which only returns null)

                                       java.lang.String sAttribute,
                                       java.lang.String sValue)

Parameters:
eParent - Parent to search within (will also be checked)
sAttribute - Desired attribute name
sValue - Desired attribute value
Returns:
First element matching that specification, or null if none
